The national crisis management policy is based on: - preparation of the country for defense and defensive mobilization training of the population; - effective preliminary preparation of society for action in crises; - use of a modern and sustainable early warning system, including the national alert system; - effective interdepartmental cooperation and coordination; - continuous monitoring of potential and developing crises; - constant improvement and harmonization of the normative base, based on a comprehensive approach utilizing all available national resources at all levels-allied, national, regional, and local; - creation of a flexible mechanism for the accelerated deployment of military capabilities and expertise to respond to crises in the absence of a civilian alternative; - maintaining sufficient reserves of resources to ensure societal autonomy during crises; - interaction and cooperation in crisis management at regional and international levels; - availability of a communication strategy providing coordinated, timely, clear, transparent, and widely accessible information about ongoing events, actions taken, expected results, and subsequent developments; - encouragement of insurance use as a tool to provide additional funding for quicker and more effective recovery after crises, disasters, and accidents, which will ensure the necessary adaptability of the national security system.
The national crisis management system includes: the National Situational Center, departmental and regional situational centers, and others engaged during crises.

The national crisis management system guarantees activities for crisis prevention and control within the country or outside it-while fulfilling obligations arising from international treaties to which the Republic of Bulgaria is a party.

The system aims to maintain national security in an optimal state, increase the manageability of state bodies with active involvement of citizens and their organizations, and operate effectively to implement this strategy.

The strategy's goals can only be achieved with a normatively regulated and institutionally organized process of dialogue, consultation, and interaction between the legislative, executive, and judicial branches, the President of the Republic, citizens, and their organizations.

High-quality dialogue, consultations, and interaction between the three branches of government and the elements protecting the national security system can be achieved by developing and implementing a unified system of standards describing the main concepts and principles of operation.
The presence of these standards will enhance operational compatibility and work efficiency.

Laws and subordinate normative acts in the field of national security are improved according to the dynamics of social relations and in accordance with principles and guidelines indicated in the strategy.

The normative framework is built and developed to achieve a unified legal space in the area of national security, preventing contradictions between legal norms, institutional and functional structures, and mechanisms.
The state ensures system transparency towards citizens and supports the capacity building of civil society for activities in national security interests.

The National Assembly, in national security matters, adopts laws, the National Security Strategy, doctrines, and other documents within its competence, setting the parameters of national security policy.
It assesses its status and the fulfillment of duties by state institutions and issues recommendations to state authorities, local government bodies, citizens, and their organizations.
The President's powers in implementing national security policy are defined in the Constitution and laws.
The Consultative Council for National Security forms the political-advisory level in the national security system.
Implementation of national security policy is carried out by central and territorial executive authorities.
Local governments and judiciary bodies contribute according to their competencies.
System effectiveness depends on mutual trust and cooperation between state institutions, private sector, NGOs, citizens, and partner countries for information exchange and joint actions.
The Council of Ministers reports on the implementation of the National Security Strategy through an annual report to the National Assembly.
The report is prepared by the executive administration in coordination with the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, higher education institutions, and experts from the non-governmental sector.
Intermediate priorities and resources for national security policy are determined by the Council of Ministers in consultation with the President and relevant permanent parliamentary committees.
They establish the necessary functional and structural organization for this purpose.
Institutional capacity is built on the principles of continuous functional interaction and operational autonomy.
The simultaneous existence of duplicate structures and excessive concentration of powers, competencies, and resources in one institution is not allowed.

The toolkit for managing and functioning of the national security system includes: - analysis and assessment of the security environment and trends and undertaking preventive actions; - timely and adequate information exchange; - planning, preparation, and management of implementation; - application of a broad and systemic interinstitutional approach; - coordination in the work of competent institutions and organizations; - methodology and methods for assessing the security system and its components in relation to their resource support and achieved results; - mechanisms to assess undertaken actions and achieved results to increase their effectiveness and efficiency; - establishment of an internal control system and correction of the national security system.
They coordinate the operational implementation of state policy and provide necessary consultation to the government and respective state bodies in preparing and implementing their decisions.
The activity of the Security Council at the Council of Ministers, its secretariat, and regional security councils is assisted by central and territorial executive bodies and by engaging experts.
Financing is conducted through a separate program within the Council of Ministers' budget.

Security services, and when needed, public order services, regardless of their subordination, perform their national security protection activities independently or coordinated within the intelligence community.

The intelligence and security services carry out activities for: - uncovering, preventing, and counteracting covert attacks against national interests and actions that threaten or damage political, economic, and defense capabilities; - protecting national security and counteracting international terrorism and its financing, as well as extremism, organized crime, drug trafficking, illegal distribution of products and technologies under international control, weapons of mass destruction, money laundering, and other risks and threats against the interests of the Republic of Bulgaria and its allies and partners; - protecting and affirming national historical and spiritual values and cultural heritage, including documents from the National Archival Fund; - acquiring information necessary for making strategic decisions to preserve and increase the well-being of citizens, society, and the state and for their development; - protecting the functions and security of Bulgarian military contingents participating in operations and missions abroad; - counteracting hybrid threats and other new forms of threats to national and allied security, including in cyberspace; - ensuring the safety of the higher state authorities.

The intelligence and security services carry out activities for: - uncovering, preventing, and counteracting covert attacks against national interests and actions that threaten or damage political, economic, and defense capabilities; - protecting national security and counteracting international terrorism and its financing, as well as extremism, organized crime, drug trafficking, illegal distribution of products and technologies under international control, weapons of mass destruction, money laundering, and other risks and threats against the interests of the Republic of Bulgaria and its allies and partners; - protecting and affirming national historical and spiritual values and cultural heritage, including documents from the National Archival Fund; - acquiring information necessary for making strategic decisions to preserve and increase the well-being of citizens, society, and the state and for their development; - protecting the functions and security of Bulgarian military contingents participating in operations and missions abroad; - counteracting hybrid threats and other new forms of threats to national and allied security, including in cyberspace; - ensuring the safety of the higher state authorities.
The implementation of foreign and domestic security policies, defense policy, and other sectoral policies is carried out with the active use of the potential of intelligence and security services.

The Council of Ministers enhances the efficiency of intelligence and security services by improving structures, personnel capacity, financing mechanisms, introducing modern technical and special means, and improving the social status of employees.

The state builds a normatively and resource-secured subsystem of programs, institutions, and flexible organizational forms for training and qualification enhancement of employees in state institutions, as well as citizens and their organizations.
State institutions apply flexible forms for utilizing the professional capacity and experience of Bulgarian citizens after their release from state service in the national security field.

The state creates and/or ensures effective functioning of specialized units in state higher education institutions and scientific organizations for training and qualification improvement of employees in national security and defense.
The training and qualification system provides general and specialized preparation for supporting and developing the national security and defense sector.

The Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, higher education institutions, other state educational and scientific structures, and civil society organizations conduct scientific research and activities to accumulate knowledge and experience and develop innovative solutions related to security and defense.
The Security Council at the Council of Ministers, together with academic representatives, develops and proposes to the Council a National Research and Innovation Program in security and defense.
Democratic control over the security system is exercised by the National Assembly and civil society organizations.
Executive authorities report to the National Assembly and provide information to civil society in accordance with legal requirements.
The National Assembly exercises parliamentary control over the activities of the national security system.

The updated National Security Strategy of the Republic of Bulgaria uses a comprehensive approach to security and defines national interests, as well as the tools and policies for their realization and protection in the context of a dynamically changing security environment, with new risks and threats.

The Council of Ministers, upon the proposal of the Security Council, makes a decision to conduct a strategic review of national security and, if necessary, proposes to the National Assembly the updating of this strategy.
